R. China. College of New Energy China University of Petroleum (East China) Qingdao 266580 P. R. China To obtain high-activity catalysts for aquathermolysis at low temperatures, a composite modification method of KOH and silane coupling agent KH570 was used to successfully prepare modified lotus stem biochar (MLSB), and six catalysts with different ZrO2 and MoO3 contents (5–30 %) were synthesized by impregnation method. MLSB and catalysts were analyzed by SEM, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms, surface pore size, and FT-IR. The results revealed that the pores of raw lotus stem biochar were increased and enlarged, and some -OH on the surface was replaced by hydrophobic groups to form hydrophobic supports. Catalysts had hydrophobic and strong acidic sites. The catalytic activities were evaluated by aquathermolysis experiments. Catalysts exhibited satisfying abilities to catalyze aquathermolysis at low temperatures (130–200 °C). Specifically, 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB catalyst displayed the optimal heavy oil viscosity reduction rate (86.1 %) at 200 °C, which was attributed to hydrophobicity, more active components and strong acid sites. The highest viscosity reduction rate of heavy oil was obtained with 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB at 200 °C and a catalyst content of 3 wt%. Continuing to increase the catalyst content decreased the viscosity reduction rate, likely due to catalyst agglomeration hindering the contact between the active component and heavy oil. Moreover, the viscosity reduction effect of the catalyst increased with higher reaction temperatures. Additionally, a reaction network of aquathermolysis catalyzed by ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB was proposed. These findings contribute to the development of efficient catalytic systems for aquathermolysis and provide insights into the application of biochar-based catalysts in heavy oil viscosity reduction. Introduction Heavy oil recovery technology, which promotes heavy oil to become a new growth point in oil and gas development and an important raw material for advanced chemical products, is ensuring a steady increase in crude oil production in the long term [1,2]. However, the recovery of heavy oil remains challenging due to its high viscosity and poor fluidity. The most common and widely used method of in situ viscosity reduction is thermal recovery by steam injection [3,4]. It is well-known that aquathermolysis is an important chemical reaction in heavy oil thermal recovery. A challenge of thermal oil recovery is to reduce the temperature of aquathermolysis. In order to meet the recovery with low energy consumption, many methods have been investigated, among which the development of more active catalysts is an effective way because catalysts can reduce the reaction activation energy and the reaction temperature window [5–8]. Dispersed catalysts can be dispersed in oil or water, which increases the contact area between catalysts and oil or water, thus allowing more active sites to function. Dispersed catalysts avoid the deactivation of conventional catalysts [9]. Therefore, this kind of catalyst is attracting much attention. Catalysts with precious metals (i.e., Pt, Ir, Pd, Rh, etc.) as active components have desirable viscosity reduction capabilities [10–13]. However, transition metals (i.e., Fe, Mo, Co, Zr, Ni, etc.) and their oxides are becoming satisfactory active components because of the high cost of precious metal materials [14–19]. Yusuf et al. [17] used disperseda NiMo oleat as a catalyst to catalyze the hydrothermal cracking reaction. The viscosity reduction was 69 % at 277 °C reaction temperature and 30 h reaction time. Lam-Maldonado et al. [18] found that NiFe as a catalyst can promote asphaltene conversion to 37.2 %−43.7 % at 372 °C. Yang et al. [19] found that the desulfurization rate at 300 °C ranged from 9.85 % to 31.26 % when using Co, Zn, Ni, and Fe metal particles as aquathermolysis catalysts, and heavy oil viscosity showed a certain decrease. Supports (i.e., SiO2, Al2O3, HZSM, TiO2, etc.) are the key factor for faster dispersion of active components and more cost-effective catalysts [20–25]. Taghili et al. [21] reported that MoO3 could well disperse on γ-Al2O3. And heavy oil viscosity reduction rate reached 86 % when 2 wt% of catalysts (γ-Al2O3/MoO3) was mixed with heavy oil at 350 ℃. The Fe0/Go catalyst prepared by Xing et al. reduced heavy oil viscosity by 64 % [22]. Lin et al. [23] reported that heavy oil viscosity could be reduced by 85 % when aquathermolysis was catalyzed using Fe3O4/HZSM-5 at 280 °C for 6 h. Tajik et al. [24] found that SiO2-Graphene/MoS2 containing 10 wt% significantly reduced the viscosity of heavy oil (viscosity reduction rate up to 81 %). Xiong et al. [25] prepared Ni/NC catalysts and found that the catalysts were involved in the aquathermolysis to reduce the heavy oil viscosity by 82.21 % at 240 °C. Although the addition of supports positively promotes aquathermolysis, the catalysts reported above have the disadvantages of unsatisfactory catalytic effect, high reaction temperature (above 240 °C), and complicated preparation process. Higher reaction temperatures consume more energy and are not environmentally friendly. Therefore, effective catalysts suitable for low-temperature aquathermolysis need to be explored. The development of potential supports is an important prerequisite. Biochar has the characteristics of a large specific surface area, rich functional groups, easy modification, a wide temperature window, and satisfactory dispersibility [26–32]. Therefore, biochar is widely used as the catalyst supports in multiphase catalytic fields such as pollutant treatment and tar catalytic cracking [33–41]. Gao et al. [36] synthesized biochar-loaded sulfide-modified nZVI and found that the sulfide nanohybrids exhibited excellent remediation of Cr (VI) polluted water. Xiang et al. [37] found that ball milled biochar (BM-biochar) could effectively remove tetracycline hydrochloride. Min et al. [38] investigated the effect of biochar-loaded catalysts on steam reforming of biomass tar from in situ pyrolysis of wood chips. The results show that biochar not only dispersed the catalyst but also improved the activity of the catalyst in tar steam reforming. Moreover, the application of biochar as supports for heavy oil reforming has also been investigated. Zhong et al. [39] prepared a catalyst of sawdust carbon loaded with nickel and reported that heavy oil viscosity could be reduced by 74.5 % in catalytic pyrolysis at 350 °C for 30 min. Tang et al. [40] found that biomass-based catalysts could reduce the viscosity of heavy oil by 95.63 % at 320 °C. Although biochar-based catalysts show satisfactory catalytic ability in heavy oil reforming, the reaction temperature exceeds 300 °C, which does not promote energy savings. The catalytic abilities of biochar-based catalysts for aquathermolysis at low temperatures has rarely been reported. To reduce the temperature, energy consumption, and cost of aquathermolysis, this study is based on the optimization of catalyst supports, and lotus stem biochar is chosen. Unlike the previous catalyst supports, lotus stem biochar has a large specific surface area and tubular channels, which provides more loading space for the active components. The characteristic of easy modification provides the potential for catalysts with low temperature activity and the ability to rapidly contact heavy oil. In this study, the potential and reaction network of the modified lotus stem biochar-based catalysts to catalyze aquathermolysis at low temperatures (130–200 °C) will be investigated. These efforts are not presently reported and are expected to provide ideas and guidance for catalytic aquathermolysis at low temperatures. Therefore, in this study, discarded lotus stems will be used for preparing catalyst supports, and the lotus stems biochar will be modified by KOH, and silane coupling agent KH570 (KH570). Different contents of ZrO2 and MoO3 will be introduced onto the surface of modified lotus stem biochar (MLSB) to synthesize a series of ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB catalysts, and the performances of six catalysts will be determined. Catalyst abilities will be evaluated by catalytic aquathermolysis experiments at different temperatures and different catalyst contents. Moreover, the possible reaction network of aquathermolysis catalyzed by ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB will be proposed. Experimental preparation Materials Initial heavy oil is taken from the Shengli oil field, and the physical property parameters of initial heavy oil are shown in Table 1 . The density and viscosity of initial heavy oil at 50 ℃ are 0.92 g/cm3 and 24,135 mPa·s, respectively. The heavy component of initial heavy oil is 47.3 % and the light component is 53.7 %. Heavy oil is dehydrated and then reused in experiments. Lotus stem (from Baoding, Hebei, China), KOH (≥85 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), silane coupling agent KH570 (Xingfeilong Chemical Co., Ltd, Jinan, China), C2H5OH (99.7 %, Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., LTD, Tianjin, China), Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (98.5 %, Maclean Biochemical Technology Co., LTD, Shanghai, China), and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (99 %, Shanghai McLean Bio-Technology Co., Ltd., China). Ltd.) were used for the preparation of supports and catalysts in this study. Tetrahydronaphthalene (C10H12, 97 %, Maclean Biochemical Technology Co., LTD, Shanghai, China), Al2O3 (≥94 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd), n-heptane (n-C7H16, 99 %, Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., LTD, Tianjin, China), C2H5OH (99.7 %, Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., LTD, Tianjin, China), toluene (C7H8, 99.5 %, Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., LTD, Tianjin, China), and Na2SO4 (99 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) were used for evaluating catalysts. All reagents are of analytical grade and used without further purification. Preparation of supports and catalysts The preparation procedure of supports and catalysts is shown in Fig. 1 . Lotus stems were cut into pieces, washed, and dried at 100 °C for 24 h. The pieces were broken into powder in a blender. Lotus stem powder was carbonized in a tube furnace at 700 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere to prepare lotus stem biochar (LSB). LSB was modified with KOH and KH570. LSB and KOH in the ratio of 1:1 were added to deionized water and stirred for 4 h. After drying at 105 °C for 8 h, the mixture was pyrolyzed at 700 °C for 3 h under a nitrogen atmosphere (heating rate 15 °C/min). The obtained material was washed to neutral (pH=7) and dried at 105 °C for 3 h. After grinding the KOH modified lotus stem biochar into powder, it was mixed with the modified agent (the mixture of KH570, anhydrous ethanol, and deionized water) and stirred for 4 h. The mixture was dried for 8 h and then washed with deionized water to neutral (pH=7). The dried material was ground to a powder. Catalyst supports were obtained, denoted as MLSB. MLSB was immersed in a mixed solution (Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) and stirred for 6 h. The mixed materials were dried at 105 °C for 12 h and then activated in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 6 h. Catalysts were obtained after grinding and sieving the obtained material into powder. Detailed descriptions of different characterization methods, for instance, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), specific surface area test, fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), and NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), were performed to determine supports and catalysts. SEM patterns were determined by a Quanta FEG 250. Specific surface area and pore size were determined by a Micromeritics ASAP 2020/2460. A Thermo fisher-Nicolet 6700 was used to determine FT-IR curves. The XPS patterns were determined by a PE PHI5300. An AutoChem II 2920 was used to determine NH3-TPD curves. Catalyst activity evaluation method The evaluation procedure of catalysts is shown in Fig. 2 . In this study, aquathermolysis with catalysts is the main method to evaluate catalyst activities. Aquathermolysis was performed in the autoclave (from Sen Long Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd, Beijing, China). The model system consists of heavy oil, water, C10H12, and catalysts. The catalyst contents were 0.05 wt%, 0.1 wt%, 0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 3 wt%, and 5 wt%. After weighing, a certain mass of the model system was placed in a reaction vessel. Before supplying the temperature, initial pressure, and stirring rate, the autoclave was purged with N2 to remove air, and the system was checked for gas tightness. The reaction temperature was 130–200 °C and the reaction pressure was 2 MPa. Reactions were continued for 24 h at a stirring rate of 300 r/min. After cooling the autoclave to room temperature, gas products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC) analyzer (Agilent 7890B) and an H2S detector (AKOOTE). Liquid-phase products of aquathermolysis were analyzed by viscosity measurement (Brookfield Company DV-II+ rotor viscosity meter), saturates aromatics resins and asphaltene fraction (SARA) analysis, elemental analysis (EA) (Elementar CHNS/O), gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC–MS) analysis (Shimadzu QP2020 NX), FT-IR (Thermo fisher-Nicolet 6700) and XPS (PE PHI5300). Additionally, the viscosity change of heavy oil was calculated by the following equation: Δ η = η − η 0 η 0 × 100 % Where η is the viscosity of the oil after the catalytic aquathermolysis. η 0 is the viscosity of the oil before treatment. Δ η is the viscosity change. Result and discussion Characteristic of the supports SEM images of the biochar The morphologies of biochar before and after modification was studied using SEM, and the results are displayed in Fig. 3 . LSB and MLSB still maintain pore structures in the form of vascular bundles of lotus stems, which indicates that carbonization and surface modification do not change overall structures of biochar. Vascular bundle structures of LSB provide more potential for active components. LSB displays fewer pores and more micro-pores (as shown in Fig. 3(a)). More and larger pores are distributed on MLSB surfaces, which facilitates the loading of more active components (as shown in Fig. 3(b)). N2 physisorption of the biochar To access the accurate pore size distribution, biochar was studied using the specific surface and pore size analyzer, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . The surface area of biochar is calculated by using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution of the biochar is deduced on the adsorption isotherm by using the density flooding theory (DFT) method. The pores of LSB are mainly micropores of 0.9 nm and mesopores of 3.5 nm. The pores of MLSB are mainly micropores of 1.2 nm and mesopores of 3.5 nm. The surface area of MLSB is 789 m2/g, which is larger than that of LSB (420 m2/g). These results further indicate that the modification method in this study effectively enhances the specific surface area and pore size of the lotus stem biochar. During KOH activation, a redox reaction between carbon and potassium compounds etches the carbon skeleton. The production of metal K embedded in the carbon lattice leads to irreversible expansion of the carbon lattice. H2O and CO2 help to further expand the pores [41]. Therefore, MLSB has larger and more pores. FT-IR of the biochar FT-IR spectroscopy was performed on biochar to study functional groups on the surface of LSB and MLSB, and the results are displayed in Fig. 5 . Peaks a-i in Fig. 5 are attributed to hydroxyl (-OH) stretching vibrational absorption peak (peak a), CH stretching vibrational absorption peak (peak b), C = O stretching vibrational absorption peaks (peak c and peak d), CC stretching vibrational absorption peak (peak e), CO stretching vibrational absorption peaks (peak f and peak g), asymmetric stretching peaks of CO-Si and Si-O-Si tetrahedral structures (peak h), and symmetric stretching peak of Si-O-Si tetrahedral structure (peak i), respectively. In FT-IR spectra of MLSB, a new symmetric stretching peak of Si-O-Si tetrahedral structure at 812.79 cm−1 and significantly enhanced asymmetric stretching peaks of CO- Si and Si-O-Si tetrahedral structures at 1036.29 cm−1 indicate that hydrophobic groups in KH570 are effectively bound to LSB surface to form hydrophobic embedded layers. Less amount of -OH on the MLSB surface than that on the LSB surface is because some of -OH on the MLSB surface is replaced by hydrophobic groups, which indicates that MLSB is hydrophobic [42]. To further investigate the hydrophobicity of supports, LSB and MLSB were studied using contact angle determination and hydrophobicity determination, and the results are shown in Fig. S1. LSB is highly hydrophilic. The water contact angle of LSB is 36.28° (Fig. S1(a)), and LSB dissolves in water when in contact with water (Fig. S1(b)). Conversely, MLSB is highly hydrophobic. The water contact angle of MLSB is 133.04° (Fig. S1(c)), and MLSB sticks to the beaker wall or floats above the water surface after contact with the water (Fig. S1(d)). Characteristic of the catalysts XPS of the catalysts Surface compositions of catalysts were recorded by XPS characterization. XPS spectra of catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 , and the measured results are summarized in Table 2 . XPS deconvolution results for Mo 3d, Zr 3d, and O 1 s are shown in Fig. S2. Support surfaces of the six catalysts were successfully loaded with MoO3 and ZrO2 (as shown in Fig. 6). Actual values of active component contents have certain deviations from theoretical values, but the values are within a reasonable range of error (as listed in Table 2). With the increase of active component contents, corresponding peak areas in XPS spectra increase, which indicates that the active component contents of catalysts are reasonable. Mo 3d XPS results of different catalysts are displayed in Fig. S2(a), (d), (g), (j), (m), and (p). Mo 3d is deconvoluted to four peaks: Mo 3d3/2 (MoO3) (235.8 eV), Mo 3d5/2 (MoO3) (232.7 eV), and Mo 3d (sub-oxide) (230.9 eV and 234.4 eV). Zr 3d XPS results of different catalysts are displayed in Fig. S2(b), (e), (h), (k), (n), and (q). Peaks at 183.0 eV and 185.3 eV are attributed to Zr 3d5/2 (ZrO2), while peaks at 179.2 eV, 181.0 eV, 181.9 eV, and 182.8 eV are attributed to sub-oxide. Sub-oxide states with low binding energies were generated by repeated X-ray scans. O 1 s XPS peaks of different catalysts are displayed in Fig. S2(c), (f), (i), (l), (o), and (r), and the related O 1 s XPS results of catalysts are given in Table S1. O 1 s is deconvoluted to two peaks, attributed to lattice oxygen (labeled as Oα) at 530.37 eV and chemisorbed oxygen (labeled as Oβ) at 532.56 eV. The percentage of lattice oxygen increased from 33.20 ar.% to 64.60 ar.% with the increase of active component contents (as listed in Table S1). Lattice oxygen is favorable for the oxidation of elements and catalysis of active components, but the stacking of metal oxides may affect catalyst performance in aquathermolysis. FT-IR of the catalysts FT-IR spectroscopy of catalysts was carried out, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . The peak at 3436.50 cm−1 is attributed to the hydroxyl group (-OH) stretching vibration peak. Hydroxyl groups can adsorb metal ions to form stable chelates. The intensity of the hydroxyl peak weakens with increasing active component contents, which indicates that more metal ions are adsorbed on support surfaces. The peak at 1633.85 cm−1 is attributed to C=O stretching vibration peak. The intensity of these two peaks (the peaks at 1091.24 cm−1 and 798.19 cm−1) decreases with the increase of active component contents, which is because some functional groups are covered by active components. Peaks located at 620.30 cm−1 and 469.77 cm−1 are attributed to telescopic vibrational peaks of the Mo-O-Mo structure and Zr-O structure, which indicate the presence of MoO3 and ZrO2 on support surfaces. The intensities of the Mo-O-Mo structure and Zr-O structure peaks increase with the increase of active component contents, which is consistent with XPS results. Furthermore, the peak at 1091.24 cm−1 is attributed to the asymmetric stretching of CO-Si and Si-O-Si tetrahedral structures, while the peak at 798.19 cm−1 is attributed to the symmetric telescopic vibrational peak of Si-O-Si tetrahedral structure, which means that catalysts are hydrophobic. To verify the hydrophobicity of catalysts, the contact angle determination results of six catalysts are displayed in Fig. S3. Water contact angles for six catalysts are 105.01° (5 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB), 100.78° (10 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB), 95.25° (15 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB), 92.56° (20 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB), 90.44° (25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB), and 90.31° (30 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB), respectively. It is further characterized that catalysts are hydrophobic although the hydrophobicity of catalysts decreases with the increase in active component contents. Hydrophobic catalysts can be easily entered and dispersed in heavy oil, which more effectively promotes catalysts to catalyze aquathermolysis at low temperatures. NH3-TPD of the catalysts The NH3-TPD profile of LSB, MLSB, and catalysts with different ZrO2 and MoO3 contents is shown in Fig. 8 . LSB and MLSB form two peaks, while six different catalysts all form three peaks. Desorption peaks at low (around 120 ℃) and high (around 600 ℃) temperatures correspond to weak and strong acid sites desorption of NH3, respectively [43]. LSB and MLSB do not have strong acid sites. After loading active components on the MLSB surface, catalysts increase strong acid sites. Areas of NH3 desorption peaks indicate the amount of acid. The increase in the high temperature desorption peak area indicates that catalysts have more strong acid sites. Strong acid sites accelerate the transfer of H + and electrons to effectively promote aquathermolysis. Catalysts activity evaluation Aquathermolysis is used to evaluate the performance of six catalysts. Aquathermolysis is mainly for the conversion of long-chain hydrocarbons to short-chain hydrocarbons, where chemical bonds are broken (e.g. C-S, CC, CO). Active components can effectively reduce the activation energy of aquathermolysis and promote breakage of chemical bonds at low temperatures. There are five evaluation criteria for aquathermolysis used in this study: heavy oil viscosity, SARA, elemental content, FT-IR, GC–MS, and gas production rate. Effect of catalysts on catalytic aquathermolysis In this study, the effects of six catalysts with different active component contents in aquathermolysis with hydrogen donors were evaluated at a reaction temperature of 200 °C and a catalyst content of 3 wt%. The heavy oil viscosity reflects small molecule production. the H/C magnitude reflects the number of saturated carbon atoms. Fig. 9(a) displays the viscosity versus H/C of heavy oil before and after treatment. The viscosity of heavy oil before treatment is 24,135 mPa·s, and H/C is 0.1407, which indicates that heavy oil before treatment contains more unsaturated carbon atoms. Saturated carbon atom amounts in heavy oil are inversely proportional to viscosity. The effect of catalysts on heavy oil viscosity reduction increases and then decreases gently with increasing active component content. The catalyst loaded with 25 % ZrO2 and MoO3 shows the best contribution with 86.1 % viscosity reduction for heavy oil, associated with 8.5 % H/C variability for heavy oil. The highest viscosity reduction efficiency can be ascribed to multiple support pores and multiple active components. The viscosity reduction effect of the catalyst loaded with 30 % ZrO2 and MoO3 is weakened compared to that of the catalyst loaded with 25 % ZrO2 and MoO3. The reason may be that when the amount of ZrO2 and MoO3 increases, metal oxides stack together and contribute to a reduction in catalytic activity. The viscosity reduction can be ascribed to hydrophobic groups on catalyst surfaces, which allows catalysts to promote aquathermolysis in the oil-water interface at low temperatures. Changes of SARA for heavy oil before and after treatment with six catalysts are shown in Fig. 9(c). After treatment, the macromolecules (asphaltene and resin) in heavy oil are converted into micromoles (saturate and aromatic) to various degrees, which leads to a viscosity reduction of heavy oil. Hydrodesulfurization reaction, which leads to the conversion of some S elements in heavy oil into H2S, is one of the steps in aquathermolysis. Therefore, in this study, we plotted the S content of heavy oil versus concentrations of H2S produced before and after treatment (Fig. 9(b)). Changes in the concentration of H2S from aquathermolysis are consistent with changes in heavy oil viscosity. After catalytic aquathermolysis, the degree of S content reduction in heavy oil increases and then decreases smoothly. The catalyst loaded with 25 % ZrO2 and MoO3 shows a 21.1 % reduction of S element in heavy oil after treatment and the reaction produced 483 ppm H2S. The catalyst loaded with 25 % ZrO2 and MoO3 shows the best desulfurization effect, which can be attributed to the fact that more C-S bonds are weakened by ligand compounds formed from Zr and Mo with sulfur-containing compounds. To further understand the formation of small hydrocarbons and the breakage of C-S bonds, we performed FT-IR (Fig. 9(d)) and GC–MS (Fig. 9(e)) analysis of solid-phase products. In Fig. 9(d), the intensity of methyl and methylene peaks (2930, 2850, and 1460 cm−1) increases after catalytic aquathermolysis. That is to say, alkyl side chains have been cleaved into small hydrocarbons during aquathermolysis. Heavy oil treated by the catalysts loaded with 25 % of ZrO2 and MoO3 has the lowest intensity of C-S bond absorption peaks (at 570–705 cm−1), which is in agreement with the results of Fig. 9(b). In Fig. 9(e), the most long-chained carbon of C21-C40 breaks into short-chained carbon of C7-C20 catalyzed by the catalyst loaded with 25 % ZrO2 and MoO3, which is consistent with the results of viscosity change in Fig. 9(a) and SARA change in Fig. 9(c). In addition, gas products were tested and the results are shown in Table 3 . The production of H2 increases steeply with increasing intensity of aquathermolysis, which can be attributed to catalysts promoting the conversion of hydrogen radicals in the reaction system. As H2 concentrations increase, the water-gas shift reaction (WGSR) proceeds toward the direction of CO production, and more hydrogen radicals are produced, which will better facilitate the cycling of the hydrothermal cracking reaction. The decrease in the production of i-C5H12 and the increase in the production of n-C4H10 may be attributed to the conversion of i-C5H12 to n-C4H10 promoted by ZrO2. Total organic gas production rates increase due to MoO3 preventing carbon deposition on catalyst surfaces. These results do not increase with increasing active component content, which is related to the stacking of metal oxides. Effect of catalyst contents on catalytic aquathermolysis Increasing catalyst contents can further promote aquathermolysis. However, excessive catalysts may be more agglomerated in heavy oil, which means that less active components contact heavy oil and do not continue to accelerate aquathermolysis. In this study, the effects of catalyst contents (0.05wt%, 0.1wt%, 0.5wt%, 1wt%, 3wt%, and 5wt%) in aquathermolysis with hydrogen donors and 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB were evaluated at a reaction temperature of 200 °C. Fig. 10(a) displays the variation of viscosity and H/C with catalyst contents. The viscosity of heavy oil is decreased and then increased with catalyst contents. When the catalyst content is 3 wt%, the viscosity of heavy oil decreases to 3366 mPa·s and reaches the maximum viscosity reduction rate. The viscosity reduction rate decreases instead when the catalyst content continues to increase to 5 wt%. The viscosity reduction effect at a catalyst content of 5 wt% is worse than that at 3 wt%, which indicates that the agglomeration of catalysts in heavy oil will weaken catalytic effects if the catalyst continues to be added. This means that 3 wt% is the ideal catalyst content. The same results are in H/C. Saturated carbon atoms in heavy oil increase as viscosity decreases, with a maximum catalyst content of 3 wt%. The changes of SARA for heavy oil before and after treatment are shown in Fig. 10(b). After catalytic aquathermolysis treatment, heavy fractions of heavy oil are significantly reduced and light fractions are obviously increased. Moreover, this phenomenon was most obvious at the catalyst content of 3 wt%. Fig. 10(c) shows the carbon number distribution of heavy oil before and after catalytic aquathermolysis treatment at 200 ℃. It can be seen that the main composition of heavy oil changes from C21-C40 to C7-C20 after catalytic aquathermolysis treatment. C7-C20 shows an upward trend as the main carbon number composition and is the most at 3 wt% of catalyst content. N, S, C, and H contents in heavy oil before and after treatment are displayed in Table 4 . Aquathermolysis has no effect on the N element in heavy oil. The change in S element content indicates that more active components contacting with heavy oil can promote the breaking of C-S bonds, which is consistent with the change in H2S production rates (Table 5 ). The changes in C element content and H element content are similar to that of S element content. Gas products were determined and the results are shown in Table 5. Changes in gas production rates are consistent with changes in viscosity and SARA. Aquathermolysis self-cycling occurs continuously with the increase of catalyst contents. When the catalyst content exceeded 3 wt%, catalysts agglomerate severely in heavy oil, preventing more active components from promoting aquathermolysis. To further investigate the promotion effect of catalysts on aquathermolysis, XPS was determined for heavy oil before and after aquathermolysis catalyzed by adding 3 wt% optimal catalyst (25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB) at 200 °C, and the results are shown in Fig. S4 and Table S2. As shown in Fig. S4(a) and (e), the C 1 s spectrum can be separated into two peaks, aliphatic or aromatic and CO bonds, respectively [44]. After catalytic aquathermolysis treatment, the aromatic and aliphatic carbon content in heavy oil increases from 28 % to 76 %, and the C atom content in oxygen-containing functional groups (hydroxyl and ether bonds) in heavy oil decreases from 72 % to 24 %. Catalytic aquathermolysis leads to the breaking of CO bonds and the increase of CC and CH bonds in heavy oil. In other words, saturated C atoms in heavy oil increase. These are consistent with the increased H/C, -CH3, and -CH2- in results. As shown in Fig. S4(b) and (f), peaks at 529.23 eV are attributed to C=O, which is mainly carbonyl oxygen of aldehydes and ketones [45]. Peaks at 533.42 eV are attributed to C-O, which is mainly located in fatty ethers, phenols, and alcohols. Peaks at 531.91 eV are attributed to O=C-O [46]. After catalytic aquathermolysis, the carbonyl oxygen content in heavy oil increases from 10.10% to 51.00 %. The CO bond content in aliphatic ethers, phenols, and alcohols increases from 7.40 % to 17.80 %. The O=C-O content decreases from 82.50 % to 31.20 %. In the hydrogenation reaction during catalytic aquathermolysis, O=C-O is converted to carbonyl oxygen, which in turn is converted to aliphatic ethers, phenols, and alcohols. As shown in Fig. S4(c) and (g), peaks at 162.99 eV are attributed to thioether, at 163.72 eV to thiophene sulfur, at 164.21 eV to sulfoxidic sulfur, at 165.03 eV to sulfones sulfur, and at 165.61 eV to acidic or sulfates sulfur. After catalytic aquathermolysis, the thioether content in heavy oil decreases from 34.00 % to 18.20 %. The thiophene sulfur content in heavy oil increases from 19.80 % to 42.00 %. The sulfoxidic sulfur content in heavy oil decreases from 27.00 % to 16.00 %. The sulfones sulfur content in heavy oil increases from 14.80 % to 18.80 %. There is no particular change in the acidic or sulfate sulfur content of heavy oil. In catalytic aquathermolysis, H2S is mainly produced from unstable sulfoxidic sulfur, sulfones sulfur, and thioether. The addition of catalysts facilitates the conversion of sulfoxidic sulfur, sulfones sulfur, and thioether to more stable thiophene sulfur and H2S at low temperatures. Sulfoxidic sulfur and sulfones sulfur remove O atoms, and then react with H2O to form aromatic hydrocarbons and thiocarboxylic acids. Thioether reacts with H2O to form thiocarboxylic acid, alkane carbon chain, and olefin carbon chain. Thiocarboxylic acid proceeds to generate H2S by the hydrodesulfurization reaction. Thiophene sulfur is also produced by the depolymerization of asphaltenes and resins [47]. Therefore, after treatment, the thiophene sulfur content in heavy oil increases significantly. As shown in Fig. S4(d) and (h), peaks at 398.93 eV are attributed to pyrrolic nitrogen, at 399.33 eV to pyridinic nitrogen, at 399.90 eV to quaternary nitrogen, and at 400.49 eV to chemisorbed NOx. After catalytic aquathermolysis, the pyrrolic nitrogen content in heavy oil decreases from 66.90 % to 36.50 %. The pyridinic nitrogen content in heavy oil increases from 13.30 % to 44.60 %. The quaternary nitrogen content in heavy oil increases from 10.00 % to 11.30 %. The chemisorbed NOx content in heavy oil decreases from 9.80 % to 7.60 %. Pyrrolic nitrogen is located at the edge of asphaltene in heavy oil and is less sTable Pyridinic nitrogen has a π-bond in the benzene ring and is more sTable In catalytic aquathermolysis, the breakage of N-containing chemical bonds mainly originates from pyrrolic nitrogen. Effect of reaction temperature on catalytic aquathermolysis To further understand the catalytic activity of catalysts at low temperatures, 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB was used for aquathermolysis with hydrogen donors at temperatures of 130–200 °C and a catalyst content of 3 wt%. Fig. 11(a) shows that thermal-only treatment and hydrogen donor treatment perform similar results, while the heavy oil viscosity is significantly reduced after catalytic aquathermolysis with hydrogen donors. This indicates that 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB can promote aquathermolysis with hydrogen donors at 130–200 ℃ to significantly improve the heavy oil viscosity reduction efficiency at low temperatures. The same promotion effect is reflected in SARA analysis (Fig. 12 ). At 130–200 °C, the asphaltene and resin content of heavy oil decrease significantly after catalytic aquathermolysis with hydrogen donors, while saturated and aromatic fractions increase significantly. From the gas production rate results of catalytic aquathermolysis with 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB (as shown in Fig. 11(b)), catalytic aquathermolysis reacts significantly at 130–200 °C. Production rates of organic gases, H2, CO, and CO2, increase with the temperature rise. These mean that the catalyst has a low-temperature catalytic effect at 130–200 °C. The determination results of H2S production concentration and S element content indicate that 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB has higher activity of promoting C-S bond breaking and S conversion compared with the effect of thermal-only and hydrogen donor effect (Fig. 11(c)). At 130–200 °C, the H2S concentration from aquathermolysis with 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB increases with the rise of reaction temperatures, especially the change is significant at 160–200 °C. C and H elemental contents and the variation of H/C are shown in Fig. 11(d). H/C of heavy oil with thermal-only treatment or hydrogen donor treatment changes weakly with the increase in temperatures. However, the H/C of heavy oil with catalyst treatment increases significantly with the increase in temperatures. In other words, after catalytic aquathermolysis with 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB, the content of saturated carbon atoms in heavy oil is significantly higher, which means that the viscosity of heavy oil decreases significantly. The carbon number distribution of heavy oil at 130–200 ℃ is provided in Fig. 13 . At 130–200 °C, C7-C20 increases weakly and C21-C40 decreases slightly after thermal-only treatment and hydrogen donor treatment, while the presence of catalyst 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB effectively promotes the change of carbon number distribution. The results show significant changes in C7-C20 and C21-C40 after aquathermolysis treatment at 130–200 °C in the presence of catalyst 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB, which indicates that the catalyst has satisfactory catalytic activity at 130–200 °C. A comparison of catalyst performance for heavy oil viscosity reduction in this study with those in other studies is shown in Table 6 . With a similar viscosity reduction effect, the applicable temperature of catalysts in this study is much lower than that of other studies. With the same catalyst content, catalysts in this study have a better viscosity reduction effect and lower application temperature. Therefore, catalysts in this study have a potential to reduce heavy oil viscosity at low temperatures. Reaction network According to the results of GC, GC–MS, FT-IR, and SARA, products of catalytic aquathermolysis contain H2S, short-chain carbon, and small molecules, which indicates that catalytic aquathermolysis in this study may proceed mainly with C-S breakage. According to Fig. S4(c), Fig. S4(g), and Table S2, there are four main sulfur compounds included in heavy oil, i.e., thioether, sulfoxidic sulfur, sulfone sulfur, and thiophene sulfur. After catalytic aquathermolysis, the contents of thioether, sulfoxidic sulfur, and sulfone sulfur in heavy oil decrease, while the content of thiophene sulfur increases. Therefore, the catalytic aquathermolysis reaction network with series ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB in this study is proposed as shown in Fig. 14 . Thioether proceeds directly to hydrodesulfurization reaction. Sulfoxidic and sulfone sulfur firstly remove O and then proceed to hydrodesulfurization reaction. Hydrodesulfurization reaction proceeds under the catalytic combination of hydrogen donors, H2O, catalysts, and heating, producing H2S, short-chain carbon, and small molecules. This agrees with the experimental results that aquathermolysis produced more H2S and C7-C10. Thiophene sulfur is more stable because C-S is located within cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and desulfurization process is more complex [48]. Thioether, sulfoxidic sulfur, and sulfone sulfur may turn into thiophene sulfur during the reaction. These agree with the experimental results presented in Fig. S4 and Table 4. Thiophene sulfur undergoes hydrolysis reaction and produces alcohols, which include thiols and enols [49]. Thiols continue to hydrolyze and produce H2S, short-chain carbon, and small molecules. The oxidation of enols produces aldehydes, which are catalytically decomposed to produce CO, H2S, short-chain carbon, and small molecules. WGSR proceeds spontaneously with the generation of CO, and H2 produced by WGSR promotes hydrodesulfurization reaction, which agrees with the experimental results that the aquathermolysis produced H2, CO, and CO2. Conclusion In this study, carbonization and modification of waste lotus stems were used to prepare catalyst supports. Six catalysts ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB with different ZrO2 and MoO3 contents were prepared by an impregnation method. The characterization of MLSB and catalysts was analyzed by SEM, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms, surface pore size, FT-IR, and wettability determination. Capacities of catalysts were evaluated by catalytic aquathermolysis at low temperatures. The conclusions are as follows: (a) LSB modified with KOH and KH570 not only has a larger specific surface area and pore size but also added hydrophobic groups on the surface. The six catalysts are hydrophobic and have strong acidic sites. Although more strong acid sites can improve the viscosity reduction ability of the catalyst, the stacking of metal oxides will reduce the contact area with heavy oil and affect the catalytic effect. Therefore, under the same conditions, the catalyst 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB shows the best catalytic ability in the catalytic aquathermolysis, rather than the catalyst 30 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB. (b) For 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB, a significant catalytic effect is present at 130–200 °C. The viscosity reduction rate increases with increasing reaction temperatures. Particularly, it can reduce the heavy oil viscosity by 86.1 % at 200 °C. As catalyst contents increase, viscosity reduction rates increase and then decrease. The highest viscosity reduction rate of heavy oil is achieved at a catalyst content of 3 wt%, but continuing to increase the catalyst content decreases the viscosity reduction rate. This is because more catalysts will agglomerate in the heavy oil and the catalytic effect will be weakened. (c) After aquathermolysis, the content of thioether, sulfoxidic sulfur, and sulfone sulfur in heavy oil decreases while the content of thiophene sulfur increases. Thioether, sulfoxidic sulfur, and sulfone sulfur break C-S by hydrodesulfurization reaction. Thiophene sulfur is stable and is desulfurized by a deep desulfurization reaction. Moreover, thioether, sulfoxidic sulfur, and sulfone sulfur may be converted to thiophene sulfur in aquathermolysis. (d) The heavy oil aquathermolysis in the presence of modified lotus stem biochar-based catalysts reduces heavy oil viscosity at 200 ℃ by 86.1 %. The modification of the raw lotus stem biochar promotes that the catalysts have the ability to get into the heavy oil faster and the low-temperature activity, which is the key to improving heavy oil upgrading at low temperatures catalyzed by lotus stem biochar-based catalysts and the foundation for further catalyst design. The injection of modified lotus stem biochar-based catalysts into reservoirs is a potential approach for low-temperature in-situ upgrading, which not only irreversibly reduces viscosity but also enhances oil recovery. However, the activity and stability of the catalysts at lower temperatures need further laboratory and field experimental data to more effectively reduce the energy consumption of heavy oil aquathermolysis. coredata.dc:description: To obtain high-activity catalysts for aquathermolysis at low temperatures, a composite modification method of KOH and silane coupling agent KH570 was used to successfully prepare modified lotus stem biochar (MLSB), and six catalysts with different ZrO2 and MoO3 contents (5–30 %) were synthesized by impregnation method. MLSB and catalysts were analyzed by SEM, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms, surface pore size, and FT-IR. The results revealed that the pores of raw lotus stem biochar were increased and enlarged, and some -OH on the surface was replaced by hydrophobic groups to form hydrophobic supports. Catalysts had hydrophobic and strong acidic sites. The catalytic activities were evaluated by aquathermolysis experiments. Catalysts exhibited satisfying abilities to catalyze aquathermolysis at low temperatures (130–200 °C). Specifically, 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB catalyst displayed the optimal heavy oil viscosity reduction rate (86.1 %) at 200 °C, which was attributed to hydrophobicity, more active components and strong acid sites. The highest viscosity reduction rate of heavy oil was obtained with 25 % ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB at 200 °C and a catalyst content of 3 wt%. Continuing to increase the catalyst content decreased the viscosity reduction rate, likely due to catalyst agglomeration hindering the contact between the active component and heavy oil. Moreover, the viscosity reduction effect of the catalyst increased with higher reaction temperatures. Additionally, a reaction network of aquathermolysis catalyzed by ZrO2 −MoO3/MLSB was proposed. These findings contribute to the development of efficient catalytic systems for aquathermolysis and provide insights into the application of biochar-based catalysts in heavy oil viscosity reduction.
coredata.dc:title: Experimental study on modified lotus stem biochar-based catalysts for heavy oil aquathermolysis
